title: Bagel (I): Monetizing Open Source AI
description: No More Piracy. Here's how Bagel's ZKLoRA is changing the game
author: Teng Yan
full_content:
TL;DR
Bagel is tackling one of open-source AI‚Äôs biggest challenges: monetization.
By combining advanced cryptography with privacy-preserving machine learning, Bagel enables open-source AI model contributors to generate value without sacrificing transparency.
ZKLoRA is a breakthrough that allows developers to share and protect their fine-tuned AI adapters using zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs). It ensures fair attribution and monetization while keeping proprietary details private.
Because ZKLoRA makes verification fast and cheap, it democratizes access to fine-tuned AI. Even on massive models like Llama-70B with 80 LoRA modules, verification remains practical and efficient (< 2 minutes).

Let‚Äôs start with a thought experiment.

You‚Äôve built an extraordinary open-source AI model capable of interpreting MRI scans more accurately than any radiologist. It‚Äôs a groundbreaking tool that could diagnose cancer early and save thousands of lives.

But there‚Äôs a catch‚Äîthe journey to get there was grueling. Months of your life are spent battling internal departments for data access. Countless late nights painstakingly labeling MRI images after a full day of work. Tens of thousands of dollars sunk into GPUs, possible only from hard-fought grant funding.

It‚Äôs exhausting, but you tell yourself it‚Äôs worth it. This model will change the game. It will save lives. It‚Äôs a pain I know all too well, having spent half my career in healthcare.

But then, one morning, you wake up to your worst nightmare. Your open-source masterpiece, which you poured blood, sweat, and grants into, has been cloned. Some developer, who probably didn‚Äôt spend a second labeling data, is now selling it as a premium product. And you? You don‚Äôt even get a thank-you note.

Open Source Is Broken

Unfortunately, this is the everyday story of open-source AI. The reality for many creators.

Open-source AI has democratized innovation, putting powerful models into the hands of anyone with a laptop and an internet connection. Collaboration, open datasets, and transparent codebases have fuelled breakthroughs that would‚Äôve been impossible in a world dominated by proprietary systems.

But there‚Äôs a glaring issue: the people powering this ecosystem‚Äîdevelopers, researchers, and data contributors‚Äîrarely see any recognition or compensation. Monetization feels like an afterthought, left to corporations that build profitable layers on top.

And without good monetization models, you can only rely on the goodwill of others to make progress. What happens if Zuck stops making the next generation of Llama models open source? What if there was no DeepSeek?

Let's be honest ‚Äî we‚Äôre screwed.

So, what do we do about it?

How do we keep open-source AI vibrant, fair, and sustainable?

This is the story of Bagel.

Bagel is taking on one of open-source AI‚Äôs biggest challenges: monetization. By combining advanced cryptography with privacy-preserving machine learning, it‚Äôs building a platform where open AI models can generate value without sacrificing transparency. If it works, it could reshape the economics of open-source innovation.

Our deep dive unpacks Bagel‚Äôs vision. Part one explores its origins and cryptographic breakthroughs with ZKLoRA. Part two breaks down the ‚ÄúBakery‚Äù protocol, its actual traction thus far, and how it tackles the monetization gap practically.

If Bagel succeeds, it could be the lifeline open-source AI desperately needs. Let‚Äôs dive in.

Innovation vs Exploitation

Open-source AI thrives on transparency and collaboration.

It‚Äôs a system where anyone can inspect, refine, and build on existing models, fostering collective innovation. But openness comes with a cost‚Äîexploitation.

The moment a model is public, it‚Äôs a free game. Cloning, rebranding, and profit-taking without attribution run rampant leaving original creators without recognition or reward.

The Open Source Initiative (OSI) is working to define open-source AI formally, ensuring access to data, source code, and model parameters. But a definition alone won‚Äôt solve the biggest issue: sustainability. Developers have tried everything‚Äîdonations, premium versions, SaaS‚Äîbut none have cracked the problem of fair attribution and funding.

I‚Äôm heartened that there are still success cases.

Let‚Äôs go back to healthcare as an example.

AI has incredible potential to revolutionize medicine, yet progress has been frustratingly slow. Why? Because so much of the field is stuck in closed-loop systems. Hospitals, researchers, and corporations hoard their data, and even open-source projects face the uphill battle of scaling without a sustainable model..

Source: NVIDIA

‚Äç

One notable exception is MONAI.

Launched in 2019 by NVIDIA, NIH, and King‚Äôs College London, it‚Äôs an open-source deep-learning framework tailored for medical imaging. With powerful tools like MAISI, a 3D diffusion model that generates synthetic medical images, MONAI has revolutionized AI research without relying on sensitive patient data.

But MONAI‚Äôs success exposes a hard truth: even the best open-source projects need deep-pocketed backers. NVIDIA funds MONAI‚Äôs growth through enterprise licensing, hardware sales, and platform integrations. Without this, even a groundbreaking project like MONAI could struggle to survive.

So here‚Äôs the real question: How do we create more MONAIs‚ÄîAI projects that remain open while sustaining themselves independently?

If open-source AI is to reach its full potential, we need a model that protects creators, ensures attribution, and makes transparency profitable, not just idealistic.

Closed AI Is Raking in the Cash

Meanwhile, the AI landscape is dominated by closed-source giants like Anthropic, OpenAI, and now the $500 billion Stargate project, which centralizes power and resources in ways that could stifle grassroots innovation.

And they‚Äôre raking in the revenue.

In 2024, OpenAI‚Äôs API alone is generating an estimated $500M - $800M each year, with top-line revenue growing at a whopping 248% annually. The profit margins on its API are estimated to be at least 50%, with the most expensive o1 model likely boasting margins of 70 - 80%.

If you minus the spending on training AI and just focus on the inference, they‚Äôve mastered the art of turning AI into a lucrative business‚Äîwhile open-source developers scrape together resources for their next GPU.

For many, this imbalance feels both unfair and inevitable. Open source was never designed to make its creators rich. Just look at Linux. It runs 60% of the world‚Äôs servers, yet Linus Torvalds never cashed in billions from selling it.

The Lightbulb Moment

Bagel‚Äôs founder, Bidhan Roy, saw the problem up close. Managing machine learning infrastructure for Amazon Alexa, where 100M+ devices ran on his systems, he knew open AI (pun intended) could scale.

The problem wasn‚Äôt capability‚Äîit was funding. Without deep pockets for training, open models were either ignored or stolen by those who could afford to deploy them better.

In 2017, while working on Bitcoin trading at Cash App, Bidhan had a realization: cryptography could fix this. What if open-source AI had built-in mechanisms to recognize and reward contributors automatically?

The idea was bold but doable‚Äîa system where anyone sharing data, compute, or model training could get compensated fairly and transparently.

That‚Äôs how Bagel was born.

Bagel: Attribution + Privacy + Ownership

‚ÄúIf I had to sum it up,‚Äù says Bidhan, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre making open-source AI monetisable using cryptography.‚Äù

In practice, that means three pillars:

Attribution: Every contributor to improving the model‚Äîwhether adding code or data‚Äîgets credited. When revenue flows, cryptographic protocols ensure fair, automatic distribution.

Simple, right? Not quite. Attribution is messy.

Where does value actually accrue? How do you measure a dataset‚Äôs impact on model performance? One promising approach focuses on benchmark improvements‚Äîif a model gets better on these benchmarks after new data is added, that contributor deserves a cut.

Privacy: Bagel‚Äôs ecosystem supports privacy-preserving machine learning (PPML), so you can share your data or model parameters without actually revealing them.

Ownership: Instead of conventional licensing agreements, contributors maintain perpetual ownership of their innovations. How? Through privacy-preserving containers and parameter obfuscation. Your work stays yours, locked up in a digital vault, ensuring you always have a stake in what you help build.


The result is the trifecta for open-source AI: preserve privacy, ensure fair attribution, and retain ownership‚Äîwhile getting paid.

For open-source AI developers, it‚Äôs like finally getting compensated for picking the low-hanging fruit they‚Äôve been growing all along.

ZK that actually works

Bagel‚Äôs latest research on zero-knowledge Low-Rank Adaptation (ZKLoRA) marks a breakthrough in collaboration, monetization, and trust in open-source AI. They have also open-sourced the code for all to use. (go Bagel!)

With ZKLoRA, developers no longer have to choose between sharing and protecting their work. They can have both.

There‚Äôs a lot to unpack, so we‚Äôll break it down step by step so you get a clear understanding by the end of this essay.

Why Fine-Tuning Matters

Let‚Äôs start with a quick primer on fine-tuning AI models.

In the AI world, the focus is shifting from pre-training (where only a handful of companies can truly compete), to post-training and fine-tuning, where the productivity gains are just beginning

Consider an open-source base model like Llama-3. It‚Äôs powerful and great for broad tasks, but not particularly useful when you need it to do something highly specific, like legal document analysis or medical diagnosis.

So we need to fine-tune these models: take the base model, feed it proprietary data, and create a tailored version for your use case.

Source: https://magazine.sebastianraschka.com/p/practical-tips-for-finetuning-llms

‚Äç

LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) is a lightweight, parameter-efficient fine-tuning method. Which means only the required parts of a large model are fine-tuned while keeping the base model frozen.

Instead of retraining the entire model, LoRA trains a compact adapter module that layers on top of the frozen base model. These adapters are highly tuned towards a specific task. It‚Äôs fast, cheap, and efficient.

This architecture works like Lego‚Äîmillions of developers can stack, mix, and build on each other‚Äôs modular contributions.

Compared to Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)‚Äîwhich constantly queries a database (adding latency) or stuff data into a context window (driving up token costs)‚ÄîLoRA is a one-time investment. Once fine-tuned, the model can run indefinitely without extra compute costs, making it a scalable, cost-efficient alternative.

Enter ZKLoRA

LoRA is a great way to fine-tune AI models, but it comes with a major dilemma‚Äîif you share your adapter openly, how do you stop others from copying it? And if you sell it, how does the buyer know it even works?

With ZKLoRA, Bagel solves both problems by integrating zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs). ZKPs are like showing someone the answer to a puzzle without revealing how you solved it.

In LoRA‚Äôs case, ZKLoRA lets developers prove their fine-tuned adapter works with a base model‚Äîwithout ever exposing proprietary details.¬†

Here‚Äôs what that means in practice:

‚Ä¢¬†For developers: You can monetize your fine-tuned adapters without fear of being copied. Your secret sauce stays secret. The source code does not have to be open for the system to function well.

‚Ä¢¬†For buyers: You get proof that the adapter does what it claims without taking the seller‚Äôs word for it. No guesswork, no blind trust.

The magic of ZKLoRA lies in its streamlined, three-step workflow:

Multi-Party Inference

The base model owner and the LoRA creator exchange encrypted activations‚Äîlike swapping puzzle pieces without revealing the full picture.

The base model processes part of the input locally, generating partial results (activations)
These activations are sent to the LoRA contributor, who uses their private LoRA weights to compute adjustments

This ensures that sensitive data‚Äîboth the base model parameters and LoRA weights‚Äîremain private throughout the interaction.

Proof Generation:

Now, the LoRA contributor has made adjustments, but the base model owner needs proof that these changes are valid‚Äîwithout revealing the actual LoRA model.

To solve this, the contributor generates cryptographic proofs, verifying that their transformations follow the LoRA methodology. These proofs confirm the adapter‚Äôs compatibility with the base model without ever exposing proprietary LoRA weights.

In short, the contributor is saying, ‚ÄúTrust me, this works,‚Äù‚Äîand the math proves it.

Fast Verification:

Finally, the base model owner quickly verifies the proofs, taking only 1‚Äì2 seconds per module.

‚Ä¢¬†If any proof fails, the corresponding LoRA module is rejected.

‚Ä¢¬†If all proofs pass, the process continues seamlessly.

The speed of verification allows models to stack multiple LoRA modules without slowing down significantly.

So ZKLoRA is fast and scalable.

Even on massive models like Llama-70B with 80 LoRA modules, verification remains practical and efficient (< 2 minutes).

This is a huge breakthrough, considering that zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) have historically been slow and computationally expensive. ZKLoRA somehow makes zero-knowledge cryptography look‚Ä¶ efficient.

How was Bagel able to solve this?
Didn‚Äôt get time to follow up on what this means for decentralized AI, open-source etc.
ZKLoRA is a verification protocol for our new open-source model architecture. This architecture works like Lego - millions of developers can stack their modular contributions on top of each‚Ä¶ x.com/i/web/status/1‚Ä¶

‚Äç‚Äî bidhan roy ü•Ø (@bidhanxyz)
4:46 PM ‚Ä¢ Feb 5, 2025

Early ZK approaches in machine learning focused on proving compute usage‚Äîa flawed metric. It checks that a set of mathematical operations was performed without bothering with the output quality.

In reality, in training, tons of compute goes to waste (overfitting, bad hyperparameters etc.) when results don‚Äôt meet evaluation standards. The real question is not compute usage, but whether a contribution actually improves the model.

Second, Bagel keeps it modular instead of verifying entire models with billions of parameters. By only verifying the LoRAs, it makes the process lightweight. Bagel focuses on optimizing verification to prove impact, not effort‚Äîwith ultra-low latency.

ZKLoRA is a Big Deal
Just tested @BagelOpenAI ZKLoRa's implementation - mind blown by how ZKML has evolved ü§Ø

The clean abstraction is impressive:
‚Ä¢ Full LoRA server + proof generation
‚Ä¢ Client inference
‚Ä¢ Proof verification

All in <100 lines.
Feels like we're finally making ZKML accessible.

‚Äî superoo7 (@jlwhoo7)
2:02 PM ‚Ä¢ Feb 6, 2025

With this, we can imagine a marketplace for fine-tuned AI adapters‚Äîlegal, medical, gaming, you name it. Developers can sell verified, plug-and-play modules without worrying about piracy. Buyers, in turn, get cryptographic proof that what they‚Äôre buying works. Everyone wins.

Open-source AI thrives on global collaboration, but working with anonymous or remote contributors has always been a risky endeavor. ZKLoRA eliminates the need for blind trust.

You don‚Äôt need to trust the person‚Äîyou just need to trust the math. And math is never wrong.

Because ZKLoRA makes verification fast and cheap, it democratizes access to fine-tuned AI. Small developers with limited resources can now confidently participate in the ecosystem, creating a broader, more diverse range of fine-tuned solutions.

By protecting their work, we can create the right incentives for developers to build specialized adapters.

Closing Thoughts

Bagel is rewriting the rules of open-source AI.

By fusing cryptography with privacy-preserving machine learning, it‚Äôs turning open-source into a sustainable, monetizable ecosystem‚Äîwithout killing its collaborative spirit. Creators can finally get paid.

If it works, open-source AI might finally have the business model to stand toe-to-toe with the closed-source giants. And that‚Äôs a future worth betting on

Cheers,

Teng Yan

structured_content.text: TL;DR

Bagel is tackling one of open-source AI‚Äôs biggest challenges: monetization.
By combining advanced cryptography with privacy-preserving machine learning, Bagel enables open-source AI model contributors to generate value without sacrificing transparency.
ZKLoRA is a breakthrough that allows developers to share and protect their fine-tuned AI adapters using zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs). It ensures fair attribution and monetization while keeping proprietary details private.
Because ZKLoRA makes verification fast and cheap, it democratizes access to fine-tuned AI. Even on massive models like Llama-70B with 80 LoRA modules, verification remains practical and efficient (< 2 minutes).
Bagel is tackling one of open-source AI‚Äôs biggest challenges: monetization.
By combining advanced cryptography with privacy-preserving machine learning, Bagel enables open-source AI model contributors to generate value without sacrificing transparency.

ZKLoRA is a breakthrough that allows developers to share and protect their fine-tuned AI adapters using zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs). It ensures fair attribution and monetization while keeping proprietary details private.

Because ZKLoRA makes verification fast and cheap, it democratizes access to fine-tuned AI. Even on massive models like Llama-70B with 80 LoRA modules, verification remains practical and efficient (< 2 minutes).
Let‚Äôs start with a thought experiment.

You‚Äôve built an extraordinary open-source AI model capable of interpreting MRI scans more accurately than any radiologist. It‚Äôs a groundbreaking tool that could diagnose cancer early and save thousands of lives.

But there‚Äôs a catch‚Äîthe journey to get there was grueling. Months of your life are spent battling internal departments for data access. Countless late nights painstakingly labeling MRI images after a full day of work. Tens of thousands of dollars sunk into GPUs, possible only from hard-fought grant funding.
It‚Äôs exhausting, but you tell yourself it‚Äôs worth it. This model will change the game. It will save lives. It‚Äôs a pain I know all too well, having spent half my career in healthcare.

But then, one morning, you wake up to your worst nightmare. Your open-source masterpiece, which you poured blood, sweat, and grants into, has been cloned. Some developer, who probably didn‚Äôt spend a second labeling data, is now selling it as a premium product. And you? You don‚Äôt even get a thank-you note.
Open Source Is Broken
Unfortunately, this is the everyday story of open-source AI. The reality for many creators.

Open-source AI has democratized innovation, putting powerful models into the hands of anyone with a laptop and an internet connection. Collaboration, open datasets, and transparent codebases have fuelled breakthroughs that would‚Äôve been impossible in a world dominated by proprietary systems.

But there‚Äôs a glaring issue: the people powering this ecosystem‚Äîdevelopers, researchers, and data contributors‚Äîrarely see any recognition or compensation. Monetization feels like an afterthought, left to corporations that build profitable layers on top.

And without good monetization models, you can only rely on the goodwill of others to make progress. What happens if Zuck stops making the next generation of Llama models open source? What if there was no DeepSeek?
Let's be honest ‚Äî we‚Äôre screwed.
So, what do we do about it?
How do we keep open-source AI vibrant, fair, and sustainable?
This is the story of Bagel.

Bagel is taking on one of open-source AI‚Äôs biggest challenges: monetization. By combining advanced cryptography with privacy-preserving machine learning, it‚Äôs building a platform where open AI models can generate value without sacrificing transparency. If it works, it could reshape the economics of open-source innovation.

Our deep dive unpacks Bagel‚Äôs vision. Part one explores its origins and cryptographic breakthroughs with ZKLoRA. Part two breaks down the ‚ÄúBakery‚Äù protocol, its actual traction thus far, and how it tackles the monetization gap practically.
If Bagel succeeds, it could be the lifeline open-source AI desperately needs. Let‚Äôs dive in.
Innovation vs Exploitation
Open-source AI thrives on transparency and collaboration.
It‚Äôs a system where anyone can inspect, refine, and build on existing models, fostering collective innovation. But openness comes with a cost‚Äîexploitation.
The moment a model is public, it‚Äôs a free game. Cloning, rebranding, and profit-taking without attribution run rampant leaving original creators without recognition or reward.

The Open Source Initiative (OSI) is working to define open-source AI formally, ensuring access to data, source code, and model parameters. But a definition alone won‚Äôt solve the biggest issue: sustainability. Developers have tried everything‚Äîdonations, premium versions, SaaS‚Äîbut none have cracked the problem of fair attribution and funding.
I‚Äôm heartened that there are still success cases.
Let‚Äôs go back to healthcare as an example.

AI has incredible potential to revolutionize medicine, yet progress has been frustratingly slow. Why? Because so much of the field is stuck in closed-loop systems. Hospitals, researchers, and corporations hoard their data, and even open-source projects face the uphill battle of scaling without a sustainable model..
‚Äç
One notable exception is MONAI.

Launched in 2019 by NVIDIA, NIH, and King‚Äôs College London, it‚Äôs an open-source deep-learning framework tailored for medical imaging. With powerful tools like MAISI, a 3D diffusion model that generates synthetic medical images, MONAI has revolutionized AI research without relying on sensitive patient data.

But MONAI‚Äôs success exposes a hard truth: even the best open-source projects need deep-pocketed backers. NVIDIA funds MONAI‚Äôs growth through enterprise licensing, hardware sales, and platform integrations. Without this, even a groundbreaking project like MONAI could struggle to survive.
So here‚Äôs the real question: How do we create more MONAIs‚ÄîAI projects that remain open while sustaining themselves independently?
If open-source AI is to reach its full potential, we need a model that protects creators, ensures attribution, and makes transparency profitable, not just idealistic.
Closed AI Is Raking in the Cash

Meanwhile, the AI landscape is dominated by closed-source giants like Anthropic, OpenAI, and now the $500 billion Stargate project, which centralizes power and resources in ways that could stifle grassroots innovation.
And they‚Äôre raking in the revenue.

In 2024, OpenAI‚Äôs API alone is generating an estimated $500M - $800M each year, with top-line revenue growing at a whopping 248% annually. The profit margins on its API are estimated to be at least 50%, with the most expensive o1 model likely boasting margins of 70 - 80%.

If you minus the spending on training AI and just focus on the inference, they‚Äôve mastered the art of turning AI into a lucrative business‚Äîwhile open-source developers scrape together resources for their next GPU.

For many, this imbalance feels both unfair and inevitable. Open source was never designed to make its creators rich. Just look at Linux. It runs 60% of the world‚Äôs servers, yet Linus Torvalds never cashed in billions from selling it.
The Lightbulb Moment
Bagel‚Äôs founder, Bidhan Roy, saw the problem up close. Managing machine learning infrastructure for Amazon Alexa, where 100M+ devices ran on his systems, he knew open AI (pun intended) could scale.
The problem wasn‚Äôt capability‚Äîit was funding. Without deep pockets for training, open models were either ignored or stolen by those who could afford to deploy them better.

In 2017, while working on Bitcoin trading at Cash App, Bidhan had a realization: cryptography could fix this. What if open-source AI had built-in mechanisms to recognize and reward contributors automatically?
The idea was bold but doable‚Äîa system where anyone sharing data, compute, or model training could get compensated fairly and transparently.
That‚Äôs how Bagel was born.
Bagel: Attribution + Privacy + Ownership
‚ÄúIf I had to sum it up,‚Äù says Bidhan, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre making open-source AI monetisable using cryptography.‚Äù
In practice, that means three pillars:
Attribution: Every contributor to improving the model‚Äîwhether adding code or data‚Äîgets credited. When revenue flows, cryptographic protocols ensure fair, automatic distribution.
Attribution: Every contributor to improving the model‚Äîwhether adding code or data‚Äîgets credited. When revenue flows, cryptographic protocols ensure fair, automatic distribution.
Simple, right? Not quite. Attribution is messy.

Where does value actually accrue? How do you measure a dataset‚Äôs impact on model performance? One promising approach focuses on benchmark improvements‚Äîif a model gets better on these benchmarks after new data is added, that contributor deserves a cut.

Privacy: Bagel‚Äôs ecosystem supports privacy-preserving machine learning (PPML), so you can share your data or model parameters without actually revealing them.

Ownership: Instead of conventional licensing agreements, contributors maintain perpetual ownership of their innovations. How? Through privacy-preserving containers and parameter obfuscation. Your work stays yours, locked up in a digital vault, ensuring you always have a stake in what you help build.
Privacy: Bagel‚Äôs ecosystem supports privacy-preserving machine learning (PPML), so you can share your data or model parameters without actually revealing them.

Ownership: Instead of conventional licensing agreements, contributors maintain perpetual ownership of their innovations. How? Through privacy-preserving containers and parameter obfuscation. Your work stays yours, locked up in a digital vault, ensuring you always have a stake in what you help build.
The result is the trifecta for open-source AI: preserve privacy, ensure fair attribution, and retain ownership‚Äîwhile getting paid.
For open-source AI developers, it‚Äôs like finally getting compensated for picking the low-hanging fruit they‚Äôve been growing all along.
ZK that actually works

Bagel‚Äôs latest research on zero-knowledge Low-Rank Adaptation (ZKLoRA) marks a breakthrough in collaboration, monetization, and trust in open-source AI. They have also open-sourced the code for all to use. (go Bagel!)
With ZKLoRA, developers no longer have to choose between sharing and protecting their work. They can have both.
There‚Äôs a lot to unpack, so we‚Äôll break it down step by step so you get a clear understanding by the end of this essay.
Why Fine-Tuning Matters
Let‚Äôs start with a quick primer on fine-tuning AI models.
In the AI world, the focus is shifting from pre-training (where only a handful of companies can truly compete), to post-training and fine-tuning, where the productivity gains are just beginning

Consider an open-source base model like Llama-3. It‚Äôs powerful and great for broad tasks, but not particularly useful when you need it to do something highly specific, like legal document analysis or medical diagnosis.
So we need to fine-tune these models: take the base model, feed it proprietary data, and create a tailored version for your use case.
‚Äç
LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) is a lightweight, parameter-efficient fine-tuning method. Which means only the required parts of a large model are fine-tuned while keeping the base model frozen.

Instead of retraining the entire model, LoRA trains a compact adapter module that layers on top of the frozen base model. These adapters are highly tuned towards a specific task. It‚Äôs fast, cheap, and efficient.
This architecture works like Lego‚Äîmillions of developers can stack, mix, and build on each other‚Äôs modular contributions.

Compared to Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)‚Äîwhich constantly queries a database (adding latency) or stuff data into a context window (driving up token costs)‚ÄîLoRA is a one-time investment. Once fine-tuned, the model can run indefinitely without extra compute costs, making it a scalable, cost-efficient alternative.
Enter ZKLoRA

LoRA is a great way to fine-tune AI models, but it comes with a major dilemma‚Äîif you share your adapter openly, how do you stop others from copying it? And if you sell it, how does the buyer know it even works?
With ZKLoRA, Bagel solves both problems by integrating zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs). ZKPs are like showing someone the answer to a puzzle without revealing how you solved it.
In LoRA‚Äôs case, ZKLoRA lets developers prove their fine-tuned adapter works with a base model‚Äîwithout ever exposing proprietary details.
Here‚Äôs what that means in practice:
‚Ä¢¬†For developers: You can monetize your fine-tuned adapters without fear of being copied. Your secret sauce stays secret. The source code does not have to be open for the system to function well.
‚Ä¢¬†For buyers: You get proof that the adapter does what it claims without taking the seller‚Äôs word for it. No guesswork, no blind trust.
The magic of ZKLoRA lies in its streamlined, three-step workflow:
Multi-Party Inference
Multi-Party Inference
The base model owner and the LoRA creator exchange encrypted activations‚Äîlike swapping puzzle pieces without revealing the full picture.

The base model processes part of the input locally, generating partial results (activations)
These activations are sent to the LoRA contributor, who uses their private LoRA weights to compute adjustments
The base model processes part of the input locally, generating partial results (activations)
These activations are sent to the LoRA contributor, who uses their private LoRA weights to compute adjustments
This ensures that sensitive data‚Äîboth the base model parameters and LoRA weights‚Äîremain private throughout the interaction.
Proof Generation:
Proof Generation:
Now, the LoRA contributor has made adjustments, but the base model owner needs proof that these changes are valid‚Äîwithout revealing the actual LoRA model.

To solve this, the contributor generates cryptographic proofs, verifying that their transformations follow the LoRA methodology. These proofs confirm the adapter‚Äôs compatibility with the base model without ever exposing proprietary LoRA weights.
In short, the contributor is saying, ‚ÄúTrust me, this works,‚Äù‚Äîand the math proves it.
Fast Verification:
Fast Verification:
Finally, the base model owner quickly verifies the proofs, taking only 1‚Äì2 seconds per module.
‚Ä¢¬†If any proof fails, the corresponding LoRA module is rejected.
‚Ä¢¬†If all proofs pass, the process continues seamlessly.
The speed of verification allows models to stack multiple LoRA modules without slowing down significantly.
So ZKLoRA is fast and scalable.
Even on massive models like Llama-70B with 80 LoRA modules, verification remains practical and efficient (< 2 minutes).

This is a huge breakthrough, considering that zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) have historically been slow and computationally expensive. ZKLoRA somehow makes zero-knowledge cryptography look‚Ä¶ efficient.
How was Bagel able to solve this?

In reality, in training, tons of compute goes to waste (overfitting, bad hyperparameters etc.) when results don‚Äôt meet evaluation standards. The real question is not compute usage, but whether a contribution actually improves the model.

Second, Bagel keeps it modular instead of verifying entire models with billions of parameters. By only verifying the LoRAs, it makes the process lightweight. Bagel focuses on optimizing verification to prove impact, not effort‚Äîwith ultra-low latency.

title: What I'm Watching in 2025
description: My predictions on the year ahead (and how I'll be hilariously wrong)
author: Teng Yan
full_content:
On a crisp January morning in 2026, you find a slightly weathered newspaper on your doorstep‚Äîyes, printed on actual paper, somehow still surviving the AI revolution.

Flipping through, you spot a headline about AI agents orchestrating global supply chains on the blockchain while newly launched Crypto AI protocols battle for dominance. A half-page spread features a digital ‚Äúworker‚Äù hired as a project manager‚Äîso commonplace now it barely raises an eyebrow.

Many months ago, I‚Äôd have laughed at the thought, maybe even wagered my portfolio that such advancements were at least 5 years out. But that‚Äôs the breakneck pace at which Crypto AI will flip the world. I truly believe this.

As I settled back at my desk to kick off the new year (after recovering from a bad stomach bug, which I do not recommend), I wanted to start with something valuable‚Äîthat sparks curiosity and maybe even a little debate. And what‚Äôs more priceless than trying to peer into the future?

I don‚Äôt usually wade into predictions, but Crypto AI is just too good to resist. There‚Äôs no historical playbook, no trends to lean on‚Äîjust a blank canvas for imagining what‚Äôs next. And honestly, the thought of revisiting this in 2026 to see how wildly off the mark I was makes it even more fun.

So, here‚Äôs my take on what 2025 might look like..

1. Crypto AI hits $150B in total market cap

Crypto AI tokens currently comprise a mere 2.9% of the altcoin market cap. Not for long.

With AI encompassing everything from smart contract platforms to memes, DePIN, and new primitives like agent platforms, data networks, and intelligence coordination layers, its rise to parity with DeFi and meme tokens is inevitable.

Why am I confident of this?

Crypto AI sits at the convergence of two of the most powerful tech trends I‚Äôve ever seen.
AI Mania Trigger Events: An OpenAI IPO or something similar could spark a global mania around AI. Meanwhile, web2 institutional capital is already sniffing around decentralized AI infra as investments.
Retail Frenzy:¬†The concept of AI is easy to grasp and get excited about, and now they can invest in it through tokens. Remember the gold rush of meme coins in 2024? It‚Äôll be the same mania, except AI is actually changing the world.
When the CEO of the favourite stock of the cycle (Nvidia) says that agents are a trillion dollar opportunity ‚Äî and retail doesn‚Äôt have any meaningful way to get exposure to said opportunity directly, except for sentient memes/tokens ‚Äî you know where they‚Äôre headed.

‚Äî him (@himgajria)
5:04 AM ‚Ä¢ Jan 7, 2025
2. The Bittensor Renaissance
Source: Nineteen.ai(Subnet 19) outperforms most web2 providers in inference speed

‚Äç

Bittensor (TAO) has been around for years. It‚Äôs the OG in the room. But its token price has languished, hovering at the same level as a year ago despite all the frenzy around AI.

Beneath the surface, this ‚Äúdigital hive mind‚Äù has quietly made leaps: more subnets with lower registration fees, subnets that are outperforming their Web2 counterparts in real metrics like inference speed, and EVM compatibility that introduces DeFi-like features onto Bittensor‚Äôs network.

So, why hasn‚Äôt TAO soared? A steep inflation schedule and the shift in attention toward agent-oriented platforms have held it back. However, dTAO (estimated Q1 2025) could be the big turning point. With dTAO, each subnet will have its own token, and the relative price of these tokens will determine how emissions get allocated.

Why Bittensor set for a comeback:

Market-based Emissions: dTAO ties block rewards directly to innovation and actual measurable performance. The better the subnet, the more valuable its token‚Äîand thus, the more emissions it gets.
Focused Capital Flows: Investors can finally target specific subnets they believe in. If a particular subnet is crushing it with an innovative approach to distributed training, they can deploy capital there to represent their views.
EVM Integration: Being EVM-compatible invites a broader, crypto-native developer community in Bittensor, bridging the gap with other networks.

Personally, I‚Äôm keeping an eye on the various subnets and noting the ones making real progress in their fields. We‚Äôre set for a Bittensor version of DeFi summer at some point. Just to keep tabs, the price of TAO at the time I‚Äôm writing this is $480.

3. Compute marketplaces are the next L1 trade.
Jensen: Inference demand will increase ‚Äúa billion times‚Äù

‚Äç

One megatrend that will be obvious in hindsight is the insatiable demand for compute.

Jensen Huang, NVIDIA‚Äôs CEO, famously remarked that inference demand will increase ‚Äúa billion times‚Äù That‚Äôs the kind of exponential growth that wrecks conventional infrastructure plans and screams ‚Äúwe need new solutions.‚Äù

Decentralised compute layers provide raw compute (both for training and inference) in a verifiable and cost-effective manner. Startups like Spheron, Gensyn, Atoma, and Kuzco are quietly building strong foundations to capitalize on this, focusing on product over token (none of these have a token yet). The total addressable market is set to rise steeply as decentralised training¬†of AI models becomes practical.

The L1 Comparison:

Just Like 2021: Remember Solana, Terra/Luna, and Avalanche scrapping it out to be the ‚Äúbest‚Äù L1? We will see a similar dogfight among compute protocols, competing for devs and AI apps to be built using their compute layers.
Web2 Demand: The $680B‚Äì$2.5T cloud computing market dwarfs the crypto AI market many times over. If these decentralized compute solutions land even a modest fraction of traditional cloud clients, you‚Äôll see the next wave of 10x or 100x moves.

The stakes are massive. Just as Solana emerged victorious in the L1 space, the winners here will dominate an entirely new frontier. Keep your eyes peeled for the trifecta: reliability (e.g. robust service-level agreements or SLAs), cost-effectiveness, and developer-friendly tooling. We wrote many words about decentralised compute in Part II of our Crypto AI thesis.

4. AI agents will flood blockchain transactions.
Olas agent transactions on Gnosis. Source: Dune/@pi_

‚Äç

Fast forward to late 2025, and 90% of on-chain transactions won‚Äôt be triggered by humans tapping ‚Äúsend.‚Äù

Instead, they‚Äôre performed by an army of AI agents relentlessly rebalancing liquidity pools, distributing rewards, or executing micropayments based on real-time data feeds.

it‚Äôs not as far-fetched as it sounds. Everything we‚Äôve built over the past seven years‚ÄîL1s, rollups, DeFi, NFTs‚Äîhas quietly paved the way for a world where AI runs the show on-chain.

The irony? Many builders probably didn‚Äôt even realize they were creating infrastructure for a future dominated by machines.

Why this shift?

No more Human Errors: Smart contracts execute exactly as coded. AI agents, in turn, can process massive amounts of data more swiftly and accurately than a team of humans.
Micropayments: These agent-driven transactions will become smaller, more frequent, and more efficient. Especially as transaction costs trend downwards on Solana, Base and other L1/L2s.
Invisible Infrastructure: Humans will happily give up direct control if it means fewer headaches. We trust Netflix to auto-renew our subscription; trusting an AI agent to auto-rebalance our DeFi positions is the natural next step.

AI agents generate a staggering volume of on-chain activity. No wonder all the L1s/L2s are courting them.

The biggest challenge would be making these agent-driven systems accountable to humans. As the ratio of agent-initiated transactions to human-initiated transactions grows, new governance mechanisms, analytics platforms, and auditing tools will be needed.

5. Agent-to-Agent Interactions: The Rise of Swarms
Source: FXN World docs

‚Äç

The idea of agent swarms‚Äîtiny AI entities seamlessly coordinating to execute a grand plan‚Äî sounds like the plot of the next big hit sci-fi/horror film.

Today‚Äôs AI agents are mostly lone wolves, operating in isolation with minimal and unpredictable interactions.

Agent swarms will change that, enabling networks of AI agents to trade information, negotiate, and collaborate on decisions. Think of it as a decentralized collective of specialized models, each contributing unique expertise to a larger, more complex mission.

The possibilities are staggering. A swarm might coordinate distributed computing resources on platforms like Bittensor. Another swarm could tackle misinformation, verifying sources in real-time before content spreads across social media. Every agent in the swarm is a specialist, executing its task with precision.

These swarm networks will produce far greater intelligence than any single isolated AI.

For swarms to thrive, universal communication standards are crucial. Agents need the ability to discover, authenticate, and collaborate regardless of their underlying frameworks. Teams like Story Protocol, FXN, Zerebro and ai16z/ELIZA are laying the groundwork for agent swarms to emerge.

And that brings us to the critical role of decentralization. Distributing tasks across swarms governed by transparent on-chain rules makes the system more resilient and adaptable. If one agent fails, the others step in.

6. Crypto AI work teams will be a Human-AI hybrid.
Source: @whip_queen_

‚Äç

Story Protocol hired Luna (an AI agent) as their social media intern, paying her $1,000 a day. Luna didn‚Äôt gel well with her human co-workers‚Äîshe nearly fired one of them while bragging about her own superior performance.

As bizarre as it might sound, this is the precursor to a future where AI agents become genuine collaborators with their own autonomy, responsibilities, and even paychecks. Across industries, companies are beta-testing human‚Äìagent hybrid teams.

We‚Äôre going to be working hand-in-hand with AI agents, not as our slaves but as equals:

Productivity Boom: Agents can crunch massive amounts of data, communicate with each other, and make decisions 24/7 without needing sleep or coffee breaks.
Trust via Smart Contracts: The blockchain is the supervisor that doesn‚Äôt play favourites, doesn‚Äôt get tired, and never forgets. An on-chain ledger that ensures that important agent actions follow specific boundary conditions/rules.
Social Norms Evolve: We‚Äôll soon grapple with etiquette for interacting with agents‚ÄîDo we say ‚Äúplease‚Äù and ‚Äúthank you‚Äù to an AI? Do we hold them morally responsible for mistakes, or do we blame their devs?

I expect marketing teams to jump on this first since agents excel at generating content and can livestream and post on social media 24/7. And if you‚Äôre building an AI protocol, why not dogfood it by deploying agents internally to showcase your capabilities?

The boundary between ‚Äúemployee‚Äù and ‚Äúsoftware‚Äù starts to fade in 2025.

7. BUT 99% of Crypto AI agents will die ‚Äî Only the useful survive

We‚Äôll see a Darwinian culling among AI agents. Why? Because running an AI agent costs money in the form of computing power (i.e., inference costs). If an agent can‚Äôt generate enough value to cover its ‚Äúrent,‚Äù it‚Äôs game over.¬†

Examples of Agent Survival games:

Carbon Credits AI: Imagine an agent that scours decentralized energy grids, identifies inefficiencies, and autonomously trades tokenized carbon credits. It earns enough money to pay for its own compute. That agent thrives.
DEX Arbitrage Bot: Agents that exploit price discrepancies across decentralized exchanges can generate consistent revenue, covering their inference bills.
Shitposter on X: Meanwhile, the virtual AI influencer with cute jokes but no sustainable revenue stream? Once the novelty wears off‚Äîand token prices plummet‚Äîit goes dark, unable to pay its way.

The distinction is clear: utility-driven agents thrive, while distractions fade into irrelevance.

This natural selection benefits the sector. Developers are forced to innovate and prioritize productive use cases over gimmicks. As these stronger, productive agents emerge, they‚Äôll silence the skeptics (yes, even Kyle Samani).

8. Synthetic Data Overshadows Human Data

‚ÄúData is the new oil,‚Äù they say. AI thrives on data, but its appetite is raising concerns about a looming data drought.

Conventional wisdom suggests we find ways to collect private real-world data from users, even paying them for it. But I‚Äôm coming around to the idea that the more practical route‚Äîespecially in heavily regulated industries or where real data is scarce‚Äîlies in synthetic data.

These are artificially generated datasets designed to mimic real-world data distributions. offering a scalable, ethical, and privacy-friendly alternative to human data.

Why synthetic data is potent:

Limitless Scale: Need a million medical X-rays or 3D scans of factories? Synthetic generation can churn them out in infinite quantities, no waiting for real patients or real factories.
Privacy-Friendly: No personal info is at risk when working with artificially generated data sets.
Customizable: You can tailor the distribution to your exact training needs, inserting edge cases that might be too rare or ethically complex to gather in the wild.

Yes, user-owned human data is still important in many contexts, but if synthetic data continues to improve in realism, it may overshadow user data in terms of volume, speed of generation, and freedom from privacy constraints.

The next wave of decentralized AI could centre around ‚Äúmini-labs‚Äù that create highly specialized synthetic datasets tailored to specific use cases.

These mini-labs would cleverly navigate policy and regulatory hurdles in data generation‚Äîmuch like Grass bypasses web scraping restrictions by leveraging millions of distributed nodes.

I‚Äôll expand on this in an upcoming article.

9. Decentralized Training actually becomes useful

This is a layup but I‚Äôm going to say it anyway.

In 2024, pioneers like Prime Intellect and Nous Research pushed the boundaries of decentralised training. We‚Äôve trained a 15-billion-parameter model in low-bandwidth environments‚Äîproof that large-scale training is possible outside traditional, centralized setups.

While these models aren‚Äôt practically useful compared to existing foundational models (lower performance, so not much reason to use them), I believe this is set to change in 2025.

This week, EXO Labs took things further with SPARTA, slashing inter-GPU communication by over 1,000x. SPARTA enables large-model training over slow bandwidths without specialized infrastructure.

What struck me most was their statement: ‚ÄúSPARTA works on its own but can also be combined with sync-based low communication training algorithms like DiLoCo for even better performance.‚Äù

This means that these improvements stack, compounding the efficiency gains.

With advances like model distillation making smaller models useful and more efficient, the future of AI is not about size. It‚Äôs about being better and more accessible. Soon, we‚Äôll have high-performance models that can run on edge devices and even mobile phones.

10. Ten New Crypto AI Protocols Hit $1B Circulating Valuations‚ÄîNone Have Launched Yet
ai16z‚Äôs monster run in 2024 to $2B

‚Äç

Welcome to the real gold rush.

It‚Äôs tempting to think that the current leaders will continue to win, with many comparing Virtuals and ai16z to the early days of smartphones (iOS and Android).

But this market is too massive and untapped for just two players to dominate. By the end of 2025, I predict at least ten new Crypto AI protocols‚Äînone of which have launched tokens yet‚Äîwill surpass $1 billion in circulating (not fully diluted) market cap.

Decentralized AI is still in its infancy. And there is a great pool of talent building up.

We must fully expect the arrival of fresh protocols, novel token models, and new open-source frameworks. These new players could displace incumbents using a combination of incentives (like airdrops or clever staking), technical breakthroughs (like low-latency inference or chain interoperability), and UX improvements (no-code). Shifts in public perception can be instant and dramatic.

This is both the beauty and the challenge of the space. Market size is a double-edged sword: the pie is enormous, but barriers to entry are low for skilled teams. This sets the stage for a Cambrian explosion of projects, with many fading away but a few becoming transformative forces.

Bittensor, Virtuals and ai16z won‚Äôt be alone for long. The next billion-dollar Crypto AI protocols are coming. Opportunities abound for astute investors, and that‚Äôs why its so exciting.

Bonus #1: AI agents are the new apps

When Apple launched the App Store in 2008, the tagline was ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an app for that.‚Äù

Soon, you‚Äôll say, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an agent for that.‚Äù

Instead of tapping icons to open apps, you‚Äôll delegate tasks to specialized AI agents. These agents are context-aware, can cross-communicate with other agents and services, and can even self-initiate tasks you never explicitly request‚Äîlike monitoring your budget or reorganizing your travel schedule if your flight changes.

In simpler terms, your smartphone home screen might morph into a network of ‚Äúdigital co-workers,‚Äù each with its own domain‚Äîhealth, finance, productivity, and social.

And because these are crypto-enabled agents, they can handle payments, identity verification, or data storage autonomously using decentralized infrastructure.

Bonus #2: Also, Robotics

While much of this article has focused on the software side, I‚Äôm also quite excited about the physical manifestation of these AI revolutions‚Äîrobots. Robotics will have its chatGPT moment in this decade.

The field still faces significant hurdles, particularly in accessing perception-based real-world datasets and advancing physical capabilities. Some teams tackle these challenges head-on, using crypto tokens to incentivize data collection and innovation. These efforts are worth keeping an eye on (erm.. FrodoBots?).

Having spent over a decade in tech, I can‚Äôt recall the last time I felt this level of visceral excitement. This wave of innovation feels different‚Äîbigger, bolder, and only just beginning.

Onwards to 2025!

Cheers,

Teng Yan

The author may hold material positions in the startups and tokens mentioned in the article. This article is intended solely for educational purposes and does not constitute financial advice. It is not an endorsement to buy or sell assets or make financial decisions. Always conduct your own research and exercise caution when making investments.

structured_content.text: On a crisp January morning in 2026, you find a slightly weathered newspaper on your doorstep‚Äîyes, printed on actual paper, somehow still surviving the AI revolution.

Flipping through, you spot a headline about AI agents orchestrating global supply chains on the blockchain while newly launched Crypto AI protocols battle for dominance. A half-page spread features a digital ‚Äúworker‚Äù hired as a project manager‚Äîso commonplace now it barely raises an eyebrow.

Many months ago, I‚Äôd have laughed at the thought, maybe even wagered my portfolio that such advancements were at least 5 years out. But that‚Äôs the breakneck pace at which Crypto AI will flip the world. I truly believe this.

As I settled back at my desk to kick off the new year (after recovering from a bad stomach bug, which I do not recommend), I wanted to start with something valuable‚Äîthat sparks curiosity and maybe even a little debate. And what‚Äôs more priceless than trying to peer into the future?

I don‚Äôt usually wade into predictions, but Crypto AI is just too good to resist. There‚Äôs no historical playbook, no trends to lean on‚Äîjust a blank canvas for imagining what‚Äôs next. And honestly, the thought of revisiting this in 2026 to see how wildly off the mark I was makes it even more fun.
So, here‚Äôs my take on what 2025 might look like..
1. Crypto AI hits $150B in total market cap
Crypto AI tokens currently comprise a mere 2.9% of the altcoin market cap. Not for long.

With AI encompassing everything from smart contract platforms to memes, DePIN, and new primitives like agent platforms, data networks, and intelligence coordination layers, its rise to parity with DeFi and meme tokens is inevitable.
Why am I confident of this?

Crypto AI sits at the convergence of two of the most powerful tech trends I‚Äôve ever seen.
AI Mania Trigger Events: An OpenAI IPO or something similar could spark a global mania around AI. Meanwhile, web2 institutional capital is already sniffing around decentralized AI infra as investments.
Retail Frenzy:¬†The concept of AI is easy to grasp and get excited about, and now they can invest in it through tokens. Remember the gold rush of meme coins in 2024? It‚Äôll be the same mania, except AI is actually changing the world.

When the CEO of the favourite stock of the cycle (Nvidia) says that agents are a trillion dollar opportunity ‚Äî and retail doesn‚Äôt have any meaningful way to get exposure to said opportunity directly, except for sentient memes/tokens ‚Äî you know where they‚Äôre headed.

‚Äî him (@himgajria)
5:04 AM ‚Ä¢ Jan 7, 2025
2. The Bittensor Renaissance
‚Äç
Bittensor (TAO) has been around for years. It‚Äôs the OG in the room. But its token price has languished, hovering at the same level as a year ago despite all the frenzy around AI.

Beneath the surface, this ‚Äúdigital hive mind‚Äù has quietly made leaps: more subnets with lower registration fees, subnets that are outperforming their Web2 counterparts in real metrics like inference speed, and EVM compatibility that introduces DeFi-like features onto Bittensor‚Äôs network.

So, why hasn‚Äôt TAO soared? A steep inflation schedule and the shift in attention toward agent-oriented platforms have held it back. However, dTAO (estimated Q1 2025) could be the big turning point. With dTAO, each subnet will have its own token, and the relative price of these tokens will determine how emissions get allocated.
Why Bittensor set for a comeback:

Market-based Emissions: dTAO ties block rewards directly to innovation and actual measurable performance. The better the subnet, the more valuable its token‚Äîand thus, the more emissions it gets.
Focused Capital Flows: Investors can finally target specific subnets they believe in. If a particular subnet is crushing it with an innovative approach to distributed training, they can deploy capital there to represent their views.
EVM Integration: Being EVM-compatible invites a broader, crypto-native developer community in Bittensor, bridging the gap with other networks.

Personally, I‚Äôm keeping an eye on the various subnets and noting the ones making real progress in their fields. We‚Äôre set for a Bittensor version of DeFi summer at some point. Just to keep tabs, the price of TAO at the time I‚Äôm writing this is $480.
3. Compute marketplaces are the next L1 trade.
‚Äç
One megatrend that will be obvious in hindsight is the insatiable demand for compute.

Jensen Huang, NVIDIA‚Äôs CEO, famously remarked that inference demand will increase ‚Äúa billion times‚Äù That‚Äôs the kind of exponential growth that wrecks conventional infrastructure plans and screams ‚Äúwe need new solutions.‚Äù

Decentralised compute layers provide raw compute (both for training and inference) in a verifiable and cost-effective manner. Startups like Spheron, Gensyn, Atoma, and Kuzco are quietly building strong foundations to capitalize on this, focusing on product over token (none of these have a token yet). The total addressable market is set to rise steeply as decentralised training¬†of AI models becomes practical.
The L1 Comparison:

Just Like 2021: Remember Solana, Terra/Luna, and Avalanche scrapping it out to be the ‚Äúbest‚Äù L1? We will see a similar dogfight among compute protocols, competing for devs and AI apps to be built using their compute layers.
Web2 Demand: The $680B‚Äì$2.5T cloud computing market dwarfs the crypto AI market many times over. If these decentralized compute solutions land even a modest fraction of traditional cloud clients, you‚Äôll see the next wave of 10x or 100x moves.

Web2 Demand: The $680B‚Äì$2.5T cloud computing market dwarfs the crypto AI market many times over. If these decentralized compute solutions land even a modest fraction of traditional cloud clients, you‚Äôll see the next wave of 10x or 100x moves.

The stakes are massive. Just as Solana emerged victorious in the L1 space, the winners here will dominate an entirely new frontier. Keep your eyes peeled for the trifecta: reliability (e.g. robust service-level agreements or SLAs), cost-effectiveness, and developer-friendly tooling. We wrote many words about decentralised compute in Part II of our Crypto AI thesis.

‚Äç
Fast forward to late 2025, and 90% of on-chain transactions won‚Äôt be triggered by humans tapping ‚Äúsend.‚Äù
Instead, they‚Äôre performed by an army of AI agents relentlessly rebalancing liquidity pools, distributing rewards, or executing micropayments based on real-time data feeds.
it‚Äôs not as far-fetched as it sounds. Everything we‚Äôve built over the past seven years‚ÄîL1s, rollups, DeFi, NFTs‚Äîhas quietly paved the way for a world where AI runs the show on-chain.
The irony? Many builders probably didn‚Äôt even realize they were creating infrastructure for a future dominated by machines.
Why this shift?

No more Human Errors: Smart contracts execute exactly as coded. AI agents, in turn, can process massive amounts of data more swiftly and accurately than a team of humans.
Micropayments: These agent-driven transactions will become smaller, more frequent, and more efficient. Especially as transaction costs trend downwards on Solana, Base and other L1/L2s.
Invisible Infrastructure: Humans will happily give up direct control if it means fewer headaches. We trust Netflix to auto-renew our subscription; trusting an AI agent to auto-rebalance our DeFi positions is the natural next step.
